extra.message: Using user input when setting headers with `header()` is potentially dangerous. This could allow an attacker to inject a new line and add a new header into the response. This is called HTTP response splitting. To fix, do not allow whitespace inside `header()`: '[^\s]+'.

cwe: CWE-113: Improper Neutralization of CRLF Sequences in HTTP Headers ('HTTP Request/Response Splitting')

extra.message: Using user input when setting headers with `header()` is potentially dangerous. This could allow an attacker to inject a new line and add a new header into the response. This is called HTTP response splitting. To fix, do not allow whitespace inside `header()`: '[^\s]+'.

cwe: CWE-113: Improper Neutralization of CRLF Sequences in HTTP Headers ('HTTP Request/Response Splitting')

extra.message: Using user input when setting headers with `header()` is potentially dangerous. This could allow an attacker to inject a new line and add a new header into the response. This is called HTTP response splitting. To fix, do not allow whitespace inside `header()`: '[^\s]+'.

cwe: CWE-113: Improper Neutralization of CRLF Sequences in HTTP Headers ('HTTP Request/Response Splitting')

extra.message: Detected non-constant file inclusion. This can lead to local file inclusion (LFI) or remote file inclusion (RFI) if user input reaches this statement. LFI and RFI could lead to sensitive files being obtained by attackers. Instead, explicitly specify what to include. If that is not a viable solution, validate user input thoroughly.

cwe: CWE-98: Improper Control of Filename for Include/Require Statement in PHP Program ('PHP Remote File Inclusion')

extra.message: The `redirect()` method does not check its destination in any way. If you redirect to a URL provided by end-users, your application may be open to the unvalidated redirects security vulnerability. Consider using literal values or an allowlist to validate URLs.

cwe: CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')
